1092472165625081856.text:
According to a 2017 analysis, WV has 219 square miles of *degraded* land that is viable for large-scale solar energy production. 

This is based on site size, proximity to electricity infrastructure and solar irradiance levels. We have the land - So why don't we have solar?

1092472036763623425.text: Sure, NC has a few dozen more sunny days on average than WV. But 164 days a year in WV is MORE THAN ZERO. And what's even better is...wait for it... we have a few hundred acres of formally-mined land that is being used for NOTHING. Nada. Zilch. We're leaving money on the table.

1092471821327192066.text:
And you know what happened when they allowed solar power in NC? Companies came. They brought jobs. Because corporations like Apple/IKEA/Google etc have set up sustainability goals to run their operations on CLEAN ENERGY. 

Only offer fossil fuels? Welp, no new jobs for you!pic.twitter.com/43GSAvvOYE

1092471628519231506.text: North Carolina for example is the 2nd highest producer of solar power (next to CA). They employ the "Solar Shepard Phenomenon": they combine solar farms with sheep farms. The sheep eat vegetation that would otherwise obscure the solar panels. Farmers diversify their land. Win Winpic.twitter.com/H7ypv4ZDVO

1092471469106319364.text:
I always thought we didn't have solar farms in WV because it wasn't particularly sunny here.

We always talk about helping coal miners get back to work. Let's do it w/ Solar.pic.twitter.com/HKpAWqNltx

Do Solar Panels work in the cold? YES!

Solar Panels work by absorbing LIGHT from the sun, not heat.

1073680330446389248.text:
So, all I'm saying, is that just because we're used to this pretty round number of 100km doesn't mean we should keep that standard now & forever. We should accept new evidence & new science & allow it to define this sort of thing. 

Oh, & congrats to VSS Unity for reaching space!

1073680233310519297.text: And because of this, the World Air Sports Federation (FAI), which maintains world records for human spaceflight-which currently defines the von Karman line as 100km - is looking to LOWER that altitude based on this new science. https://www.fai.org/news/statement-about-karman-line …

1073680151370551297.text:
Based on @planet4589's calculations - it can vary between 70km - 90km.
"For a typical satellite ballistic coefficient the effective Karman line is close to (within 10 km of) 80 km independent of solar and atmospheric conditions"
From his paper here: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094576518308221 …

1073680042108973056.text:
Well, recent work from @planet4589 shows that the boundary of space depends on many variables: position and time (because of variations in atm density due to solar activity) and lift coefficient of the spacecraft.  

So what's the *real* line of space? Basically: "it depends."

1073679977290190848.text:
While the official von Karman line is set at 100km, the Air Force uses 80km as their official boundary of space. And @virgingalactic's VSS Unity reached 82.7km yesterday and the team claimed it reached "space."

So who's right here? Is an 80km definition ~cheating~?

1073679902593839104.text:
Let's first note that there is no actual ~line of space~ 
But in general, von Karman argued, the line of space marks the altitude where where forces due to orbital dynamics exceed aerodynamic forces. 100km was chosen - but it's just a rough estimate...& it was a nice round number

1073679841201803266.text:
There seems to be some gripe about using 80km as the "line of space" when we were all taught that the von Karman line is at 100km. 

So...where does space begin?pic.twitter.com/mNd131Dam3

1067133004315877382.text:
~2:54pm ET - MarCO scheduled to give us telemetry of EDL (and possibly an image)
+~3 hours after landing - MRO scheduled to provide more EDL telemetry and imagery of its descent
+~5 hours after landing - Odyssey scheduled to tell us how the solar array deployment went.
